Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 03:31PM - edited May 18, 2012 05:06PM by FilterLady Hi Mardo: I also had a wire localization before my excisional biopsy and I didn't feel a thing! I was prepared for pain but the radiologist said I'm going to rub some numbing stuff (I'm calling it stuff since I can't remember exactly how she put it, lol), then I'll use a needle about the size of what is used for a TB test (very short) and inject some medicine that will numb deeper.  Then she said she would use a bigger needle to do the deepest numbing. She asked me to tell her when I was ready, I said go ahead.  After the first step, she told me she was getting ready to use the little needle and I might feel a sting for a second.  I felt nothing.  Then she said she was going to use the big one and that I might feel a bigger sting.  I then said go ahead and she said "I'm done".  I truly felt nothing. The worst part of it all was having to lay on my right side on that table and keep my arms above my head, lol.  My foot actually went to sleep! When the wires were inserted, I had to go to the mammo room to verify the placement, I actually saw on the monitor the wires.  The tech was so apologetic but I told her I wanted to see it! The excisional biopsy was a walk in the park!  I was home by 1pm and never even needed any pain medication! You'll do fine....waiting is truly the hardest part. Take care! LaDonna

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2014 05:22PM FilterLady wrote: I still get that fear, although not as bad as before.  I get left breast mammo done between my full mammo.  So every 6 months I'm there.  The first time after my diagnosis, I had a major meltdown when I stepped in front of the machine.  I had convinced myself and my hubby (who is always with me) that I was not nervous, worried, etc but that wasn't the way it happened at all. I thought after that first one that it would get easier and it does somewhat.  At my last full mammo, all the "regular" rooms were full so I was taken to the ultrasound room to wait.....that same room where I found out that there was definitely something there.  I was in tears by the time the doc got there thinking "here we go again".  But all was well and I am sure that the new tech didn't realize how terrifying that room was for me.   I don't have that "can't hardly breathe" fear any longer but I still have that anxiousness that I never had before my diagnosis.  I no longer have my hubby go with me (at my request) since he too has that fear in his eyes and it makes me scared too. The waiting is truly the hard part.....no way around it I guess.  I'm praying for good results for you both.  God bless y'all. LaDonna

Truebff....those tornadoes are scary.  I live in east central Mississippi and we got a storm shelter installed on our property after Hurrican Katrina.  We've only had to go in it once, thank goodness.  At least with hurricanes you get a good advance warning.  I was raised in Pascagoula on the coast and my parents live about 5 miles from the beach and got over 3 ft of water in their home.  Some people don't realize the power of that water.  There is not much warning for those tornadoes! Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2013 05:27PM FilterLady wrote: Hi Misha, I went to my regular yearly mammo appt and there was something there that was not there the year before so then I had an ultrasound and my radiologist referred me to a breast surgeon. My DH went with me to see the breast surgeon to set up an excisional biopsy.  The morning of the biopsy, I went to my radiologist to get the wire localization done then to surgery.  My DH was there holding my hand and supporting me.  He's a great note taker and he loved having a "job" since he felt so helpless. I told the surgeon I wanted my results over the phone and then would come in for a regular post surgery appt.  I got my results 2 days later and found out that it was in fact bc.  My DH was outside trying to stay busy and when we got the results, he was much more upset than I.  I got the results on a Friday so we had a few days for it to soak in and start preparing our questions.  I called my family and my DH called some of our friends and that helped too. He has been there for my appts, tests, surgery since and he can think up some good questions.  He went with me for several radiation appts and really understood how things work when the techs let him come back while I was getting "zapped" so that he could see and ask questions about them. He continues to go to follow up appts even though I tell him it's okay.  Maybe he'll be better with time.  He tries not to let me know he's worried but I know.  I let him do the worrying, lol. We attend our local breast cancer support group as do several other husbands.  My DH wants to know everything and it helps me to know if I forget to ask something, he's there with notes in hand to do so. The most important thing is to get him involved (if he wants to)so that he understands every phase of your tests, treatments (if any).  Also, get all copies of your test results and surgery since you can both refer back to those results when you see other doctors like your family doctor. Take care and let us know how you are doing. God bless you, LaDonna

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 10:13PM FilterLady wrote: I went to my regular mammo and was shocked when the radiologist said we needed to go to the ultrasound room.  She would always come in and say everything is fine, see you next year, but call if you have any concerns.  This time I could tell she was concerned.  When we went to the ultrasound room she pointed out the 2 small "areas of concern".  Neither she nor I could feel them.  She made me an appointment to see a surgeon 2 days later. My hubby was working out of town and not due back until after my appt with the surgeon.  So I had to call him so he could be there with me.  The surgeon explained what he needed to do.  I had to get a needle aspiration at the mammo place then go to the surgery center so surgeon could remove the "areas of concern". I really liked the surgeon from the start and it helped that the radiologist said if she were going to have any surgery, he would be the one to operate on her.  He removed the "lumps" 2 weeks later since the next week was the Labor Day holiday week and he would be out of town.  I told him I would like the results asap so over the phone was good for me.  I work at home so being at work was not an issue. He told me if I had not heard from his office by that Friday (2 days post surgery) to call and he would see if the results were in.  I called and had to leave a message.  His nurse called back about 2 hours later and said he needed to speak to me.  I knew then it was bc.  He told me and answered all my questions.  Hubby was out working in the yard and I called him after the surgeon told me. It really devastated him and my sons.  My mind was already in " okay what am I going to do to fix this" mode. We met with the surgeon the next week and got everything scheduled for October 5.  Preop testing on October 3 revealed suspicious mass in my left lung.  My Momma died of lung cancer so this really threw me for a loop, hubby was out of town working and I didn't tell him since he could not do anything.  I was already scheduled to get sential node injection on October 4 so a CT was scheduled before the sn injection.  I was so upset but didn't want to tell anyone and have them panic...I was doing enough of that.  But my dear daughter-in-law is going to college to be a nurse and I called her to let her know what was going on.  My son is a OTR truck driver and out of town so I did not want to tell him much.  My daughter-in-law left class to be with me during CT and sn injection.  Results of CT, indeterminate but suspect granuloma.  I had surgery on October 5, then PET Scan on October 24, granuloma diagnosis.  I have a follow up CT in March but both RO and MO are not concerned, they said it's common and we'll just watch it. I'll have my last radiation treatment (#35) this Thursday and I'm ready to ring that bell!  I have family and friends coming to celebrate the day with me!  Thanks to places like this and the breast cancer support group my hubby and I attend, we did it!  What a journey this continues to be!  There are lots of strong women on these boards!

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2012 09:24AM FilterLady wrote: Benny, I know the waiting for the testing is hard.  I had CT then PET all done because of a "something" on my left lung.  The CT was "indetermate" so I had to get a PET.  Turns out I have granuloma, not cancer.   When this first came up, I just knew I had lung cancer since I'm a former smoker (10 yr quit date in Ocotober, yeah me!) and my Momma also died from lung cancer, I was so upset while in the waiting room to have the CT that my daughter-in-law, Kristina, left her college class to sit and wait with me.  After finding that it was not cancer, I felt better but I am still a little "antsy" right before my follow up CT.   Please don't go by what the nurse read since you won't know what the final diagnosis until the path report comes in.  Whatever the results, you will get through it one step at a time.  You have a great support system and that makes everything less stressful. Take care and please let us know when you have results. God bless you, LaDonna

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 09:35AM FilterLady wrote: Hi ya'll:  I had a lumpectomy and sentiel node biopsy on October 5 and got results yesterday.  The margins were clear and the lymph nodes are all clear as well.  The only surprise is the pathology showed a .2cm of carcinoma in situ in some of the tissue.  We have an appointment with the surgeon tomorrow morning to dicuss the pathology report in depth and decide what the next step will be.  The path reports will be sent to the radiologist that first saw the tumors on mammogram and breast ultrasound as well as to an oncologist.  I want to talk to each of them after we talk with the surgeon tomorrow so we can decide how we need to proceed.  It just seems that whenever we get good news there is always a "but" that follows.  And when I did my preop for the lumpectomy, a new area of concern was seen on my chest x-ray so I had to get a CT Scan and those results were indeterminate.  The radiologist and the surgeron both think it is scar tissue so we'll have to follow up on that as well.  I don't think me or my hubby are ever going to get a good nights sleep!  Sorry for the melt down but I knew I could find words of encouragement here.  Thanks and God Bless Everyone!

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 01:19AM FilterLady wrote: ScardyCat, I had the wire localization before my excisional biopsy and it sounded scarier than it was.  The doctor took me back to the ultrasound room, located the 2 small tumors, then she said I'm going to spray a numbing agent on your breast, then I'll give you the "big" shot to numb it even more and all you will feel is a little sting.  I kept waiting for the sting and next thing I knew she was done!  The only pain I had was the position I had to lay in for the 20 minutes it took, lol.  And after she got those in, I had to go back to the mammogram room to verify they were in the correct position.  The tech had the screen turned where I could see it (by mistake, bless her heart she couldn't stop saying she was sorry that I saw it), but I wanted to see exactly what was done. Then I had to get taken to the surgery center (1 block away) by ambulance (due to liability issues) and I had to wait about 20 minutes before I was taken to surgery.   I'm not a scardy cat but it really was the most pain free procedure I've ever had.  Heck a pap smear hurt worse than that wire localization.  I have a great doctor and the fact that the patient before me was in her 70's and came out smiling didn't hurt either! Please ask your doctor for something to help you relax so that you are not so afraid. Take care and I'm hoping for B9 for you!

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2013 08:11PM FilterLady wrote: Dear YMRD, The ladies here have given you wonderful advice.  I'll add my voice to theirs....stay away from google....heck it scares me today. I was diagnosed at 55 on a screening mammogram.  I had an excisional biopsy to make the diagnosis then had a left lumpectomy and sentiel lymph node biopsy.  My cancer was caught very early and I had 35 radiation treatments and remain NED since! I have to tell you that your life will never be the same.....but for me it meant a good thing.  I really realized what was and was not important to me.  I also quit letting things I cannot control stress me out.  The best gift you can give yourself is to focus on YOU!  You will have important decisions to make and you need to gather all the info you can (this includes getting copies of EVERYTHING) from your doctors, ie test results, pathology to be able to make a decision that is right for YOU!  If possible it would help you to have someone accompany you to any appointments so they can take notes since it's very easy to forget some details. Start tonight writing down any and all questions you can think of to ask your medical team.  If you don't have someone you think can accompany you to appointments, please ask your doctor if there is a patient advocate that you can speak to or call your local American Cancer Society.  There is a lot of help available but you cannot get it if you don't know to ask. The last thing I want to say is please, please, please continue to read these boards and ask any questions you think of since the women on the boards have certainly had experience is most anything you ask about.  I never thought I would be in my new "happy place" when I was first diagnosed but the not knowing all the info and the waiting is the worst! God bless you, LaDonna

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 12:29PM FilterLady wrote: anndh:  I have larger breasts and I chose a lumpectomy and SNB since my doctors said I was an excellent candidate given that my biggest "lump" was only 3mm (yes mm not cm).  Mine was caught very early with a screening mammogram.  I'm so glad I didn't put that yearly appointment off. My surgeon said he would perform as masectomy if that's what I chose but he recommended the lumpectomy and radiation since the 5 year survival rate was the same for both.  My thinking was, I could do the "little surgery" now and IF I ever needed to, I could do the "big surgery" in the future. It is a decision that you have to make and you have to do what's best for you.  My surgeon wanted my husband to come with me to get all the facts then said "y'all talk it over but it is her decision in the end".  My husband said he would support whatever decision I thought was best. I finished radiation on January 19th and started taking letrozole the next day.  I feel better each day and am looking forward to having my whole family here for Easter.  I go to our local breast cancer support group meeting each month and continue to be inspired by the people there.  My husband goes as well as a few other husbands.   Everyone on these boards are wonderful and I continue to learn from them every day.  There is nothing you can't ask so don't be afraid or embarrased to ask, as someone here has no doubt experienced it. ((((((((((((((hugs)))))))))))))) to you!

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2012 02:37PM FilterLady wrote: I also suggest getting copies of path reports, scans, etc. I have a large pink binder that I keep that is organized by path reports, scans and also my insurance EOB and bills that come to me.  That way I can "match up" the bills to the EOB so I know what I'm supposed to pay.  My hospital only sends itemized bills on request, which I do, I don't want my insurance to pay for something I don't get. Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2012 08:48PM FilterLady wrote: Hi Carey: It's hard not to think about my breast cancer since my left breast is smaller than my right....not by much but still.  But everytime I see it I thank God that mine was found early by a great radiologist that didn't have the "wait and see" attitude.  I continue to have a great medical team that gives me that "warm fuzzy" everytime I have an appointment. The thought that it can return does cross my mind from time to time but I just believe that if it ever does, then I'll deal with it the same way I've dealt with this.  I'll get a plan, put it into action and get on with my life. I and my DH both have become very involved with raising funds for research, we go to a breast cancer support group (they've been my rock too) and try to raise awareness of the importance of regular health screenings for everyone. I was diagnosed on 9/16/11 and my DH and I decided that we needed to do whatever we could to make this journey as easy as possible for us both.  Our town has a great day of celebration, fund raising, etc every October for breast cancer awareness month. My DH ran in a high heel race for men and I entered the decorate an umbrella contest for survivors.  He looked so funny running in those heels.  There was even 1 man that dressed up as well.  I won second place in the umbrella contest.  It was a great day and I really didn't realize how many people come out to support the cause. We made it a family affair at our Relay for Life.  Me, my DH, our younges son, my brother from out of town, his daughter and her son really had a great time.  My nieces Momma lost her battle with brain cancer in January.  I got to walk my first survivors lap and this year the survivors walked a half lap and then their caregivers walked the last half lap with them.  The survivors wore purple shirts and the caregivers had a purple sash....which I hope my DH will wear when he runs in those high heels this year! Have a great vacation!

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2012 08:28PM FilterLady wrote: Hi odie....congrats on your anniversary.  I also thought I was invincible but found out I'm not.  I'm looking forward to my one year anniversary....it's been a scary and yet wonderful year for me. Me and DH spent the afternoon with our younger son (33), his wife and our 2 youngest granddaughters (ages 3 and 4) at a local waterpark.  We spent about an hour and half there before it started thundering so we left and went to a local hamburger place (Backyard Burgers) to eat.  What a wonderful way to get tired. Just watching those grandbabies having so much fun with us is so worth it.  They really love us and once we got there, they "forgot" about their Momma and Daddy. They grow up so fast and I am so blessed to have them in my life. The support here has been wonderful and I think the biggest message I've gotten is that life is short, make the most of the time you have and never think that you are alone in your fight against this demon that is breast cancer. I hope everyone has a great weekend and a wonderful 4th of July! LaDonna

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 09:12PM FilterLady wrote: Wow! How time flies.  I had my first post diagnosis, post treatment mammo on 9/27/12.  I thought I was fine and I was....up until the time I stood in front of that machine!  I had a mini meltdown right then and there....God bless those techs....they told me to take my time and take deep breaths....everything would be fine.  I had the mammo then went to the exam room.  The radiologist came in and said "All Clear" and did a breast exam!  My hubby was on pins and needles in the waiting room and almost jumped out of his chair when he saw my big smile and my thumbs up! I went back in March for a mammo on my left breast and again got an all clear.  This time there was so much less stress than that first one....still a little on edge but no nearly as bad. I'll go back in September for a mammo on both breasts and expect to keep hearing "All Clear". I'm praying that you all get good results and try not to stress out....I know....a lot easier said than done! LaDonna

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2012 04:19PM FilterLady wrote: Hi Edith: My DH and I told our sons (ages 32 & 35) as soon as the diagnosis came in and then I've kept them up to date on what's happening. They were scared for me at first since Momma died from lung cancer but now they understand that my bc is different and my prognosis is excellent.  From time to time they still have questions and I answer them as best I can.   They know the days I have appts and I'm sure to call them after I get out so they stay "in the know".  My youngest son attended this years Relay for Life so he could watch me walk my first survivor's lap.  My brother and niece also came up as well. Good luck with telling your son and daughters tomorrow.  I'm sure they will have a lot of questions for you and they will realize that this is not a death sentence but a journey that you will be making and that you will need their support now more than ever. God bless y'all, LaDonna

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2012 01:52PM FilterLady wrote: Bennymuffins: I, too, was stressed about a CT then PET since my Momma died from lung cancer on 12/31/06.  Turned out I have "granuloma" on my left lung.  I've had 4 followup CT's and it's stayed the same so in the words of my MO, "we are gonna quit zapping you every 3 months, we'll check in a year".   Talk about stress, I was so upset but my sweet daughter left the college class and came to wait with me.  She was in college to be an RN (she's graduated now, yippee!) so she was so much comfort to me.  We prayed before I even checked in for the tests and I felt so much better. Do you have a friend or relative that can go with you?  Asking for Xanax is not a bad idea either.  The scans need to be done so you can get a firm diagnosis and you don't need to have a lot of stress and high blood pressure before it.  I'm praying for good reports and that you can get something to help you with the anxiety before the tests. God bless you, LaDonna
